title: How to Make a Log Cabin for Kids

steps.headline: Gather large (about 8 or 10 inches diameter), straight, matching logs/poles.
steps.description:
It would be advisable to disinfect the logs thoroughly with diluted 30% household bleach and water (you can mix 1 gallon of bleach into 2 1/3 gallons of water, making 3 1/3 gallons of the mix, for 30% bleach and 70% for the water mixture). Use good, solid wood not containing bore worms, wood ants and such -- and not beginning to deteriorate in storage -- due to moisture/rot, fungus/mold or insects. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7d\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7d\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Make a little less than 1/3 diameter notches/dents on both sides of each, near the ends of the logs with an axe or saw.
steps.description:
Alternate the larger end and narrower ends from end to end, as natural wood will be thicker on one end (lower part of each "tree-trunk") than the other end (toward the tree-top). In the case of using 10 inch (25.4 cm) logs their notches would be 3 inches (7.6 cm) or less, leaving about 4 inches (10 cm) of wood in in the middle roughly 1/3 of the notch). This would possibly be 3 ⁄3 inches (8.5 cm) for each notch and the remaining wood -- if the logs were perfectly straight and all the same diameter, but natural logs will vary. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/15\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/15\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Place the logs on top of each other overlapping/linking them at the corners (like building with Lincoln Logs toys) and spike them together in the notch, or bore each log in line for inserting long, iron "rebars" (reinforcing bars) from above to tie it all together when the wall is up, if desired.
Stack the logs as high as you want the walls to be.
steps.description:
Keep the wall vertically aligned ("plumb") -- not leaning inward or outward. This is accomplished by cutting the logs to matching/uniform lengths, notching, sizing and straightness. Repeatedly hang several strings on nails with pointed weights called "plumb-bobs" from the top of each wall downward as you go -- so the string clears the wall a little -- to check the vertical plumb (or use a carpenter's "level") as you go. If the structure is not plumb, it might collapse inward or outward in an out-of-plumb area (non-vertical). Gravity works for you very much if the structure's wall and posts are plumb, but works against you if not. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/73\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/73\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Cut out and frame-up windows and door after the walls are in place.

Put some wooden beams forming triangular shapes using angled "rafter" beams with overhangs ("eaves") on top of the walls to hold a temporary tarp up and for nailing the roof planks over the rafter beams.
steps.description: Without eaves, there would be rain water running down the walls, causing discoloration, fungus and rot.

steps.headline: Nail the tarp or beams to the wall tops (you may want to put log braces standing on end with cross-braces to angle the tarp so water doesn't "pond/pool" in the sagging tarp.
steps.description: If using a ridge beam, nail each rafter part of the triangle and nail the planks on top of the rafter beams.

steps.headline: "Chink"/fill the spaces/cracks between the logs.
steps.description: Gather some clay and push it in between to fill in the cracks; perhaps mixing dried, dead-grass or straw to the clay for holding the clay together (concrete could be used, rather than clay of course).

steps.headline: Use any playhouse or shed pattern to build your framing including studs, window and doors frames/"casings".
Cover (close-in) the frame with stockade fencing poles which are readily available from most lumber supply stores.

The roof can be either standard watertight tar-/asphalt-paper and shingles over plywood -- or with stockade poles over top which would not be watertight/"weathered-in", but would let in rain and air, etc.
Landscaping timbers are pre-trimmed logs of uniform dimensions (perhaps only milled on two or three sides) which are fairly easy to build without cracks to chink.
Determine the dimensions of your cabin.
Determine whether or not you wish the walls to be solid or more open.
steps.description: Solid walls will require that you miter or notch the corners and build a firmer frame. Open walls require only that you drill holes in the ends for a length of stabilizing rebar to connect the timbers at the corners.

steps.headline: Determine whether you want the playhouse to be permanent or removable at a later date.
steps.description: Pour cement foundations or use strong "concrete blocks" on foundation pads (thicker and stronger than ordinary rectangular, concrete stepping stones) at the corners for a solid installation. One block at each corner and one in the middle of the building, and ones midway under each wall would be adequate for a small cabin. "Cinder blocks" are much lighter, and brittle -- and would break more easily. Lay a wooden foundation on blocks for easy removal later. A pre-cut foundation delivered on skids may be just the thing.

tyn: Tar-paper and asphalt shingles or other materials (roofing optional)
text:
Using Natural Materials Gather large (about 8 or 10 inches diameter), straight, matching logs/poles. It would be advisable to disinfect the logs thoroughly with diluted 30% household bleach and water (you can mix 1 gallon of bleach into 2 1/3 gallons of water, making 3 1/3 gallons of the mix, for 30% bleach and 70% for the water mixture). Use good, solid wood not containing bore worms, wood ants and such -- and not beginning to deteriorate in storage -- due to moisture/rot, fungus/mold or insects. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7d/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7d/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Make a little less than 1/3 diameter notches/dents on both sides of each, near the ends of the logs with an axe or saw. Alternate the larger end and narrower ends from end to end, as natural wood will be thicker on one end (lower part of each "tree-trunk") than the other end (toward the tree-top). In the case of using 10 inch (25.4 cm) logs their notches would be 3 inches (7.6 cm) or less, leaving about 4 inches (10 cm) of wood in in the middle roughly 1/3 of the notch). This would possibly be 3 ⁄3 inches (8.5 cm) for each notch and the remaining wood -- if the logs were perfectly straight and all the same diameter, but natural logs will vary. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Place the logs on top of each other overlapping/linking them at the corners (like building with Lincoln Logs toys) and spike them together in the notch, or bore each log in line for inserting long, iron "rebars" (reinforcing bars) from above to tie it all together when the wall is up, if desired. Stack the logs as high as you want the walls to be. Keep the wall vertically aligned ("plumb") -- not leaning inward or outward. This is accomplished by cutting the logs to matching/uniform lengths, notching, sizing and straightness. Repeatedly hang several strings on nails with pointed weights called "plumb-bobs" from the top of each wall downward as you go -- so the string clears the wall a little -- to check the vertical plumb (or use a carpenter's "level") as you go. If the structure is not plumb, it might collapse inward or outward in an out-of-plumb area (non-vertical). Gravity works for you very much if the structure's wall and posts are plumb, but works against you if not. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut out and frame-up windows and door after the walls are in place. Put some wooden beams forming triangular shapes using angled "rafter" beams with overhangs ("eaves") on top of the walls to hold a temporary tarp up and for nailing the roof planks over the rafter beams. Without eaves, there would be rain water running down the walls, causing discoloration, fungus and rot. Nail the tarp or beams to the wall tops (you may want to put log braces standing on end with cross-braces to angle the tarp so water doesn't "pond/pool" in the sagging tarp. If using a ridge beam, nail each rafter part of the triangle and nail the planks on top of the rafter beams. "Chink"/fill the spaces/cracks between the logs. Gather some clay and push it in between to fill in the cracks; perhaps mixing dried, dead-grass or straw to the clay for holding the clay together (concrete could be used, rather than clay of course). Using Fencing, Stockade Walls Use any playhouse or shed pattern to build your framing including studs, window and doors frames/"casings". Cover (close-in) the frame with stockade fencing poles which are readily available from most lumber supply stores. The roof can be either standard watertight tar-/asphalt-paper and shingles over plywood -- or with stockade poles over top which would not be watertight/"weathered-in", but would let in rain and air, etc. -- depending on your preferences. Using Debarked, Milled Landscaping Timbers Landscaping timbers are pre-trimmed logs of uniform dimensions (perhaps only milled on two or three sides) which are fairly easy to build without cracks to chink. Determine the dimensions of your cabin. Mark them with stakes. Determine whether or not you wish the walls to be solid or more open. Solid walls will require that you miter or notch the corners and build a firmer frame. Open walls require only that you drill holes in the ends for a length of stabilizing rebar to connect the timbers at the corners. Determine whether you want the playhouse to be permanent or removable at a later date. Pour cement foundations or use strong "concrete blocks" on foundation pads (thicker and stronger than ordinary rectangular, concrete stepping stones) at the corners for a solid installation. One block at each corner and one in the middle of the building, and ones midway under each wall would be adequate for a small cabin. "Cinder blocks" are much lighter, and brittle -- and would break more easily. Lay a wooden foundation on blocks for easy removal later. A pre-cut foundation delivered on skids may be just the thing.
sentences: Using Natural Materials Gather large (about 8 or 10 inches diameter), straight, matching logs/poles.

It would be advisable to disinfect the logs thoroughly with diluted 30% household bleach and water (you can mix 1 gallon of bleach into 2 1/3 gallons of water, making 3 1/3 gallons of the mix, for 30% bleach and 70% for the water mixture).
Use good, solid wood not containing bore worms, wood ants and such -- and not beginning to deteriorate in storage -- due to moisture/rot, fungus/mold or insects.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7d\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7d\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Make a little less than 1/3 diameter notches/dents on both sides of each, near the ends of the logs with an axe or saw.
Alternate the larger end and narrower ends from end to end, as natural wood will be thicker on one end (lower part of each "tree-trunk") than the other end (toward the tree-top).
In the case of using 10 inch (25.4 cm) logs their notches would be 3 inches (7.6 cm) or less, leaving about 4 inches (10 cm) of wood in in the middle roughly 1/3 of the notch).
This would possibly be 3 ⁄3 inches (8.5 cm) for each notch and the remaining wood -- if the logs were perfectly straight and all the same diameter, but natural logs will vary.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/15\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/15\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Place the logs on top of each other overlapping/linking them at the corners (like building with Lincoln Logs toys) and spike them together in the notch, or bore each log in line for inserting long, iron "rebars" (reinforcing bars) from above to tie it all together when the wall is up, if desired.
Stack the logs as high as you want the walls to be.
Keep the wall vertically aligned ("plumb") -- not leaning inward or outward.
This is accomplished by cutting the logs to matching/uniform lengths, notching, sizing and straightness.

Repeatedly hang several strings on nails with pointed weights called "plumb-bobs" from the top of each wall downward as you go -- so the string clears the wall a little -- to check the vertical plumb (or use a carpenter's "level") as you go.
If the structure is not plumb, it might collapse inward or outward in an out-of-plumb area (non-vertical).
Gravity works for you very much if the structure's wall and posts are plumb, but works against you if not.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/73\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/73\/Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Log-Cabin-for-Kids-Step-4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut out and frame-up windows and door after the walls are in place.

Put some wooden beams forming triangular shapes using angled "rafter" beams with overhangs ("eaves") on top of the walls to hold a temporary tarp up and for nailing the roof planks over the rafter beams.
Without eaves, there would be rain water running down the walls, causing discoloration, fungus and rot.
Nail the tarp or beams to the wall tops (you may want to put log braces standing on end with cross-braces to angle the tarp so water doesn't "pond/pool" in the sagging tarp.
If using a ridge beam, nail each rafter part of the triangle and nail the planks on top of the rafter beams.
"Chink"/fill the spaces/cracks between the logs.

Gather some clay and push it in between to fill in the cracks; perhaps mixing dried, dead-grass or straw to the clay for holding the clay together (concrete could be used, rather than clay of course).
Using Fencing, Stockade Walls Use any playhouse or shed pattern to build your framing including studs, window and doors frames/"casings".
Cover (close-in) the frame with stockade fencing poles which are readily available from most lumber supply stores.

The roof can be either standard watertight tar-/asphalt-paper and shingles over plywood -- or with stockade poles over top which would not be watertight/"weathered-in", but would let in rain and air, etc.
-- depending on your preferences.

Using Debarked, Milled Landscaping Timbers Landscaping timbers are pre-trimmed logs of uniform dimensions (perhaps only milled on two or three sides) which are fairly easy to build without cracks to chink.
Determine the dimensions of your cabin.
Mark them with stakes.
Determine whether or not you wish the walls to be solid or more open.
Solid walls will require that you miter or notch the corners and build a firmer frame.
Open walls require only that you drill holes in the ends for a length of stabilizing rebar to connect the timbers at the corners.
Determine whether you want the playhouse to be permanent or removable at a later date.
Pour cement foundations or use strong "concrete blocks" on foundation pads (thicker and stronger than ordinary rectangular, concrete stepping stones) at the corners for a solid installation.
One block at each corner and one in the middle of the building, and ones midway under each wall would be adequate for a small cabin.
"Cinder blocks" are much lighter, and brittle -- and would break more easily.
Lay a wooden foundation on blocks for easy removal later.
A pre-cut foundation delivered on skids may be just the thing.
